intro: Benthamidia florida var. urbiniana, commonly known as the Florida benthamidia, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of Florida. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its showy, tubular flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as swamps and marshes, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. Its leaves are opposite and ovate, often with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered an endangered species requiring conservation efforts.
